New Records: The Mets scored six runs in the ninth inning after being no-hit through eight frames, the most by a team in the expansion era (since 1961)
Key Match Events: Francisco Lindor hit a 398-foot home run in the top of the ninth inning to end the no-hitter threat and ignite a six-run rally
The Mets had their fair share of hard contact but even when they found their timing, the best-hit line drives seemed to find an opposing glove
Francisco Alvarez capped the rally with a three-run homer to give New York its fifth straight series win
Pre-Game Insights: The Mets' struggling offense looked to be on the verge of a reckoning on Wednesday afternoon, their offense coming three outs away from being no-hit for the ninth time in franchise history
Manager Carlos Mendoza emphasized the importance of good at-bats and eventually something good happening
Post-Match Reflections: Lindor said from the visitors' clubhouse after the game that the hit felt really good and was one of those hits that he could tell the vibes in the dugout just lifted
Manager Carlos Mendoza said that once Lindor hit that ball, you could feel it and sense the momentum shift
Miscellaneous Highlights: The Mets wore hats and gear in honor of New York's first responders, which meant a little more to Lindor on this day
This was the fifth time in franchise history that the Mets won a game after being no-hit through eight innings
The Mets have something concrete to build on as they shift to Philly for an NL East matchup
Others: Sean Manaea kept his team in it with 6 2/3 innings of one-run ball
The Blue Jays' call to the bullpen gave Lindor a chance to confer with teammates Jose Iglesias, Mark Vientos and Pete Alonso
